overview_of_class: Rosalind Krauss in her seminal 1979 essay, "Sculpture in the Expanded Field," said that, "practice is not defined in relation to a given medium?but rather in relation to the logical operations on a set of cultural terms, for which any medium?might be used." Krauss opened up the possibility for artists -especially painters - to perform operations, as practice, on the collectively held notion of what constitutes "painting." The reconsidered broad guidelines about what the medium is and can be, coupled with what philosopher Arthur C. Danto described as "pluralism" (i.e. the idea that no kind of output is more ?true,' or advanced, than another) left the terminology of painting wide open decades ago. This history has given artists room to respond, and the opportunity to respond to one-another's responses for some time now. It is important to note that these conversations between artists, while historical, have been advancing for years. In this course students will explore painting that challenges two-dimensions; bricolage, combines, installation, etc.
